page.title: 12HISTORY Pentney & Narboro'
page.content: There are the remains of a{Monastic {Priory}in Pentney which was, until recently kept in good repair. The {Church}was built in Norman times. The stump of a{Market Cross}still exists and nearby is the Pound Field. Remains of a{bone crushing factory}exist from the days when whale bones were ferried along the River Nar from King's Lynn. Narborough village was built around the Nar. Barges were used to bring grain and malt to the{Maltings}for brewing beer, some of which was sold at the{Ship,}an old coaching inn. At the rear of{Narborough Church}stands an old building (now renovated) once used as a mortuary and dwelling for the grave digger. Corn was ground at the{Mill}on the Nar; the wheel now turns for display purposes.{Narborough {Hall}was used as a hospital during the First World War.
